 APOD: 2015 August 3 - A Proton Arc Over Lake Superior












Astronomy Picture of the Day
============================

[Discover the cosmos!](archivepix.html)
Each day a different image or photograph of our fascinating universe is
featured, along with a brief explanation written by a professional astronomer.

2015 August 3
  

[![See Explanation.  Clicking on the picture will download
 the highest resolution version available.](image/1508/ProtonArc_Williams_960.jpg)](image/1508/ProtonArc_Williams_1080.jpg)




 **A Proton Arc Over Lake Superior**    

 **Image Credit & Copyright:** 
[Ken Williams](http://www.greatwatersphotography.com/about.html)

 **Explanation:** 
The setting had been picked out -- all that was needed was an aurora.
And late last August,
[forecasts predicted](http://spaceweather.com/archive.php?view=1&day=28&month=08&year=2014)
that an otherwise beautiful night sky would be lit up with
[auroral green](ap141103.html).
Jumping into his truck, the astrophotographer approached his secret site --
but only after a five hour drive across the rural
[Upper Peninsula of Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_Peninsula_of_Michigan).
What he didn't know was that his luck was just beginning.
While setting up for the image, a
[proton arc](http://auspace.athabascau.ca/handle/2149/518) -- a rare type of aurora -- appeared.
The [red arc](http://spaceweathergallery.com/indiv_upload.php?upload_id=101070) lasted only about 15 minutes, but that was long enough to capture in a 30-second exposure.
As the name indicates,
[proton arcs](http://web.stanford.edu/~mystical/Publications/spasojevic2004_arcPlume.pdf)
are caused not by
[electrons](http://www-spof.gsfc.nasa.gov/Education/whelect.html) but by more massive
[protons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proton) that
[bombard](http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2005/10jun_newstorm/) the Earth's atmosphere following an
[energetic event](ap111005.html) on the Sun.
In the [featured image](http://www.greatwatersphotography.com/p366640280/hc6084e6#hc6084e6),
the yellow lights on the horizon are the city lights of
[Marquette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marquette,_Michigan),
[Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michigan),
[USA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States).
The blue and yellow rocks in the
[Lake Superior](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NhAvpx-t15s) foreground are lit by a
[LED](http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=lighting.pr_what_are) flashlight.
Also captured, to the left of the red proton arc, was the band of our
[Milky Way Galaxy](ap150126.html).


 **APOD Editor to Speak:**  Saturday, August 8 at
[Keweenaw Science & Engineering Festival](http://www.keweenawscience.org/events.php)   

 **Tomorrow's picture:** [galaxies cluster](ap150804.html)

Each day a different image or photograph of our fascinating universe is
featured, along with a brief explanation written by a professional astronomer.

2015 August 3
  

[![See Explanation.  Clicking on the picture will download
 the highest resolution version available.](image/1508/ProtonArc_Williams_960.jpg)](image/1508/ProtonArc_Williams_1080.jpg)




 **A Proton Arc Over Lake Superior**    

 **Image Credit & Copyright:** 
[Ken Williams](http://www.greatwatersphotography.com/about.html)

 **Explanation:** 
The setting had been picked out -- all that was needed was an aurora.
And late last August,
[forecasts predicted](http://spaceweather.com/archive.php?view=1&day=28&month=08&year=2014)
that an otherwise beautiful night sky would be lit up with
[auroral green](ap141103.html).
Jumping into his truck, the astrophotographer approached his secret site --
but only after a five hour drive across the rural
[Upper Peninsula of Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_Peninsula_of_Michigan).
What he didn't know was that his luck was just beginning.
While setting up for the image, a
[proton arc](http://auspace.athabascau.ca/handle/2149/518) -- a rare type of aurora -- appeared.
The [red arc](http://spaceweathergallery.com/indiv_upload.php?upload_id=101070) lasted only about 15 minutes, but that was long enough to capture in a 30-second exposure.
As the name indicates,
[proton arcs](http://web.stanford.edu/~mystical/Publications/spasojevic2004_arcPlume.pdf)
are caused not by
[electrons](http://www-spof.gsfc.nasa.gov/Education/whelect.html) but by more massive
[protons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proton) that
[bombard](http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2005/10jun_newstorm/) the Earth's atmosphere following an
[energetic event](ap111005.html) on the Sun.
In the [featured image](http://www.greatwatersphotography.com/p366640280/hc6084e6#hc6084e6),
the yellow lights on the horizon are the city lights of
[Marquette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marquette,_Michigan),
[Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michigan),
[USA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States).
The blue and yellow rocks in the
[Lake Superior](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NhAvpx-t15s) foreground are lit by a
[LED](http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=lighting.pr_what_are) flashlight.
Also captured, to the left of the red proton arc, was the band of our
[Milky Way Galaxy](ap150126.html).

[Keweenaw Science & Engineering Festival](http://www.keweenawscience.org/events.php)

The task requires identifying the architectural firm that designed a landmark building in Chicago named after the namesake of a city whose lights were featured in a NASA Astronomy Picture of the Day in early August 2015. The city identified from the APOD is Marquette, Michigan.

The landmark building in Chicago named after Marquette is the Marquette Building. The architectural firm that designed the Marquette Building is Holabird & Roche.

As of June 2023, the firm is known as Holabird & Root. Therefore, the first name appearing in the name of the firm as of June 2023 is "Holabird."

FINAL ANSWER: Holabird

 APOD: 2015 August 3 - A Proton Arc Over Lake Superior












Astronomy Picture of the Day
============================

[Discover the cosmos!](archivepix.html)
Each day a different image or photograph of our fascinating universe is
featured, along with a brief explanation written by a professional astronomer.

2015 August 3
  

[![See Explanation.  Clicking on the picture will download
 the highest resolution version available.](image/1508/ProtonArc_Williams_960.jpg)](image/1508/ProtonArc_Williams_1080.jpg)




 **A Proton Arc Over Lake Superior**    

 **Image Credit & Copyright:** 
[Ken Williams](http://www.greatwatersphotography.com/about.html)

 **Explanation:** 
The setting had been picked out -- all that was needed was an aurora.
And late last August,
[forecasts predicted](http://spaceweather.com/archive.php?view=1&day=28&month=08&year=2014)
that an otherwise beautiful night sky would be lit up with
[auroral green](ap141103.html).
Jumping into his truck, the astrophotographer approached his secret site --
but only after a five hour drive across the rural
[Upper Peninsula of Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_Peninsula_of_Michigan).
What he didn't know was that his luck was just beginning.
While setting up for the image, a
[proton arc](http://auspace.athabascau.ca/handle/2149/518) -- a rare type of aurora -- appeared.
The [red arc](http://spaceweathergallery.com/indiv_upload.php?upload_id=101070) lasted only about 15 minutes, but that was long enough to capture in a 30-second exposure.
As the name indicates,
[proton arcs](http://web.stanford.edu/~mystical/Publications/spasojevic2004_arcPlume.pdf)
are caused not by
[electrons](http://www-spof.gsfc.nasa.gov/Education/whelect.html) but by more massive
[protons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proton) that
[bombard](http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2005/10jun_newstorm/) the Earth's atmosphere following an
[energetic event](ap111005.html) on the Sun.
In the [featured image](http://www.greatwatersphotography.com/p366640280/hc6084e6#hc6084e6),
the yellow lights on the horizon are the city lights of
[Marquette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marquette,_Michigan),
[Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michigan),
[USA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States).
The blue and yellow rocks in the
[Lake Superior](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NhAvpx-t15s) foreground are lit by a
[LED](http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=lighting.pr_what_are) flashlight.
Also captured, to the left of the red proton arc, was the band of our
[Milky Way Galaxy](ap150126.html).


 **APOD Editor to Speak:**  Saturday, August 8 at
[Keweenaw Science & Engineering Festival](http://www.keweenawscience.org/events.php)   

 **Tomorrow's picture:** [galaxies cluster](ap150804.html)

[bombard](http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2005/10jun_newstorm/) the Earth's atmosphere following an
[energetic event](ap111005.html) on the Sun.
In the [featured image](http://www.greatwatersphotography.com/p366640280/hc6084e6#hc6084e6),
the yellow lights on the horizon are the city lights of
[Marquette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marquette,_Michigan),
[Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michigan),
[USA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States).
The blue and yellow rocks in the
[Lake Superior](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NhAvpx-t15s) foreground are lit by a
[LED](http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=lighting.pr_what_are) flashlight.
Also captured, to the left of the red proton arc, was the band of our
[Milky Way Galaxy](ap150126.html).

 APOD: 2015 August 3 - A Proton Arc Over Lake Superior












Astronomy Picture of the Day
============================

[Discover the cosmos!](archivepix.html)
Each day a different image or photograph of our fascinating universe is
featured, along with a brief explanation written by a professional astronomer.

2015 August 3
  

[![See Explanation.  Clicking on the picture will download
 the highest resolution version available.](image/1508/ProtonArc_Williams_960.jpg)](image/1508/ProtonArc_Williams_1080.jpg)




 **A Proton Arc Over Lake Superior**    

 **Image Credit & Copyright:** 
[Ken Williams](http://www.greatwatersphotography.com/about.html)

 **Explanation:** 
The setting had been picked out -- all that was needed was an aurora.
And late last August,
[forecasts predicted](http://spaceweather.com/archive.php?view=1&day=28&month=08&year=2014)
that an otherwise beautiful night sky would be lit up with
[auroral green](ap141103.html).
Jumping into his truck, the astrophotographer approached his secret site --
but only after a five hour drive across the rural
[Upper Peninsula of Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_Peninsula_of_Michigan).
What he didn't know was that his luck was just beginning.
While setting up for the image, a
[proton arc](http://auspace.athabascau.ca/handle/2149/518) -- a rare type of aurora -- appeared.
The [red arc](http://spaceweathergallery.com/indiv_upload.php?upload_id=101070) lasted only about 15 minutes, but that was long enough to capture in a 30-second exposure.
As the name indicates,
[proton arcs](http://web.stanford.edu/~mystical/Publications/spasojevic2004_arcPlume.pdf)
are caused not by
[electrons](http://www-spof.gsfc.nasa.gov/Education/whelect.html) but by more massive
[protons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proton) that
[bombard](http://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/2005/10jun_newstorm/) the Earth's atmosphere following an
[energetic event](ap111005.html) on the Sun.
In the [featured image](http://www.greatwatersphotography.com/p366640280/hc6084e6#hc6084e6),
the yellow lights on the horizon are the city lights of
[Marquette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marquette,_Michigan),
[Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michigan),
[USA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States).
The blue and yellow rocks in the
[Lake Superior](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NhAvpx-t15s) foreground are lit by a
[LED](http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=lighting.pr_what_are) flashlight.
Also captured, to the left of the red proton arc, was the band of our
[Milky Way Galaxy](ap150126.html).

[Keweenaw Science & Engineering Festival](http://www.keweenawscience.org/events.php)

The task requires identifying the architectural firm that designed a landmark building in Chicago named after the namesake of a city whose lights were featured in a NASA Astronomy Picture of the Day in early August 2015. The city identified from the APOD is Marquette, Michigan.

The landmark building in Chicago named after Marquette is the Marquette Building. The architectural firm that designed the Marquette Building is Holabird & Roche.

As of June 2023, the firm is known as Holabird & Root. Therefore, the first name appearing in the name of the firm as of June 2023 is "Holabird."

FINAL ANSWER: Holabird
